model.name: Archi StyledHtml module
model.documentation:
• You have designed something, you have the Archimate model on it. But you have to create a documentation in the form requested by your client.
  • You are designing something complex. You want to make sure that you have thought about all aspects and interdependencies.
  • You work with junior architects or developers. You are tired of checking their models for trivial errors and omissions.
  • You are doing detailed design, and it is boring to do the trivial task of converting the model to config file by hand.
If any of the above happens, this module and the underlying concepts are developed for you. This module makes possible to
  • define and document enterprise architecture policies
  • check architecture models against those policies
  • define documentation styles for various stakeholders, and generate those documentations from the model
  • generate configuration and code directly from the model
This model tries to fulfill multiple purposes: - Show how Archimate can be used in the goovernance of IT - Document the styledhtml Archi module - Serve as an example for both of the above - The webpage of the styledhtml module is generated from it. See http://archistyledhtml.sourceforge.net/ You can find user documentation in the Use Cases section.

element.name: Archi community
element.documentation: Anyone who does anything related to Archi belongs here

element.name: Archi users
element.documentation: The users of Archi. All and any of them.

element.name: Archi developers
element.documentation: Everyone who develops archi or one of the modules belonging to it.

element.name: Download Archi
element.documentation: With any web browser from the Archi download site.

element.name: Archi download site
element.documentation: You can download Archi at http://archi.cetis.ac.uk/download.html

element.name: Download the StyledHtml package
element.documentation: Using any web browser, from the StyledHtml download site.

element.name: StyledHtml download site
element.documentation: It is at https://sourceforge.net/projects/archistyledhtml/files/

element.name: Install Archi
element.documentation: See http://archi.cetis.ac.uk/download/latest/Archi%20User%20Guide.pdf "Installing and Launching Archi"

element.name: install the StyledHtml package
element.documentation:
Just unzip the package in the install directory of Archi.
Further info for troubleshooting, consider it only if something goes wrong:
The package contains two jar files, which go to the "plugins" directory. The Archi directory should already contain a "plugins" directory. You don't have to unzip the jar files. If you see new directories with names like "bin" and "META-INF" then you have managed to unzip the jars...

element.name: start Archi
element.documentation: If you were already running archi this is the time to exit and restart it. You start Archi in the usual way, see http://archi.cetis.ac.uk/download/latest/Archi%20User%20Guide.pdf

element.name: Check the module
element.documentation: You should have - a "Styled Export" tab in Edit/Preferences, - a "File/Export/Model to Styled Html" menu entry, and - a "File/Export/Model to rich format" menu entry

element.name: installation
element.documentation: This is how you install the StyledHtml module for Archi

element.name: Checkout the provided styles
element.documentation: In Edit/Preferences/Styled Export Push "Install Provided Styles". Choose the directory you want to export the provided styles.

element.name: Configure the style used
element.documentation:
You may want to checkout the provided styles before doing this.
Press the modify button on the stylesheet location. Give the stylesheet location in the file dialog. Navigate to the stylesheet drectory, and choose the file named "style.xslt".

element.name: Configure output directory
element.documentation: Use the modify button and the file dialog to designate the directory you want the output be. If you check the "Don't ask for location" checkbox, then styled export won't ask you for the location when exporting. If you don't check it, the directory you have given here will be the default.

element.name: Create your own style
element.documentation:
You can create your own style using XSLT. Create a directory, place a file called "style.xslt" in it. The input of style.xslt is a rich format model, the output is "index.html". The contents of the directory containing style.xslt will be recursively copyed to the output directory, so you can place css, images, etc to the style directory.
There are also more complex scenarios, see FIXME to learn about them. You can use one of the provided styles as a starting point.

element.name: Configuration
element.documentation: This is how you configure the StyledHtml module to be able to create nice reports with it.

element.name: Create a report
element.documentation: You want to configure the style used and maybe the output dir before you do this. You use the Styled Export menu entry. If you did not check "Don't ask for location", then a file dialog wil appear, where you can define the output directory. If the directory already exists (and you did not check the "Don't ask for location" checkbox), a dialog will appear asking whether to overwrite it.

element.name: Edit your model
element.documentation: You do it in the usual way in Archi. See http://archi.cetis.ac.uk/download/latest/Archi%20User%20Guide.pdf

element.name: Preview output
element.documentation: Using the browser you can preview the report. Just point to index.html in the output dir.

element.name: Preview the export log
element.documentation:
The export log appearsh in an eventlog window. It is most useful if you have a policy related to the report. You can use it to remediate inconsitencies in your model. Clicking on the links will focus on the element which have the problem.
Hint: By clicking analysis on the properties tab, you will see the views where the element participates in, and the relations of it. You can navigate to the view by clicking on it.

element.name: Problem occured
element.documentation: If there is something wrong in the process, a problem report dialog will appear. See Troubleshooting for this case.

element.name: Look at the problem report dialog
element.documentation: The problem report dialog should give you some hint on what happened

element.name: Look at the application log
element.documentation: See application log file for the location of application log file. Look at the end of it for any hint.

element.name: application log file
element.documentation:
In the installation directory of Archi there is a file called Archi.ini Look at the definition of osgi.instance.area, looking something like this: -Dosgi.instance.area=@user.home/uk.ac.bolton/Archi
The @user.home here is your home directory. Within the directory defined by osgi.instance.area there is a file called .metadata/.log
This is the log file.

element.name: look at stdout/stderr
element.documentation: If still no solution, look at the stdout/stderr of the application. In unix, you should start it from a terminal window to achieve it, or look at the .xsession-error or similar file. See the configuration of your desktop for further details. In windows? Dunno.

element.name: Analyse problem
element.documentation: You can look at several places to figure out what have happened.

element.name: Problem identified
element.documentation: If you could identify the cause of the problem, you are happy. Now the next step is to remediate or report the problem.

element.name: No clue
element.documentation: If you don't know what caused the problem, or how to solve this, it is time to report it.

element.name: Remediate problem
element.documentation: If you can remediate the problem (e.g. it is a problem with a stylesheet or policy you have created, or there is a known workaround for a known bug), you do it, and you became very happy. If the fix needs something more (it is an unknown bug, or needs a yet unknown fix or change in the source code), please report it.

element.name: report problem
element.documentation: You can report any problem through https://sourceforge.net/p/archistyledhtml/tickets/

element.name: Being happy
element.documentation: Problem solved, congratulation.

element.name: sketchtotable
element.documentation: the sketchtotable style should be brought back to shape and documented

element.name: define the objectClass by direct property
element.documentation: An objectClass can be directly defined for an element by setting an objectClass property with the value as the objectClass name

element.name: define the objectClass by indirect property
element.documentation: Any property having a : in its name implies that the string before the : is the objectClass of the containing element. For example by setting report:part to all on a folder, we actually telling that the folder have a report objectClass, and a report specific attribute named part with the value all.

element.name: define the objectClass with a Group or Folder
element.documentation: By setting the associatedObjectClass property of a Group or a Folder, we declare that all elements in it are belonging to the objectClass named by the value of the property.

element.name: define the objectClass by specialisation
element.documentation: this does not work yet. If object A is of the objectClass Template then all objects which specialisation of A will have the objectClass named after the name of A.

element.name: objectClass
element.documentation:
The primary abstraction of the policy is the objectClass element. An objectClass describes a concept derived from either a builtin archimate element, or another objectClass: the ancestor of the objectClass.
We can define the objectClass of an archimate element in one of the following ways:
- add a property where the name is "objectClass" and the value is the name of the objectclass - add a property where the name is in the form <class>:<property>, where <class> is the name of the objectclass, and <property> is the name of one of the properties of the objectclass. The value vill be the value of the objectClass property. - create a Group in a view, with the property named "associatedObjectClass". The value of the property should be the name of the objectClass. All the elements within the group (including the nested ones) will belong to the objectClass
The policy related to the objectclass will help to check the model for structure and content, and also makes creating reports and generating configurations easier. One of the examples of this is that the policy for this model can be generated from this model, and the generated policy can be used to check that this model is indeed conforms to the policy which is generated from it :)

element.name: parent
element.documentation:
The ancestor of the objectClass. The objectclass have all the properties of its non-builtin ancestors.
The ancestor is represented by a tag named 'ancestor' having an attribute named 'class' with the value of the ancestor class name in the policy file.

element.name: there is a specialisation relationship from the ancestor to the objectClass
abstract
element.documentation:
If "true", the objectClass is merely used for the purpose of instantiating properties for other objectclasses. It should not be directly instantiated in a model.
The property is represented by the attribute with the same name in the policy file.
FIXME: check for this is not implemented yet.

element.name: attrib
element.documentation: The id of an attribute belonging to the objectClass

element.name: A composition relationship points from here to the attribute
attribute
element.documentation: The attribute is used to describe a attribute of an objectClass. You can define a attribute value either by giving the value to a property named classname:attributename to an object, or by using a model structure defined by the defaults of the given attribute.

element.name: type
element.documentation:
The type of the property. It will be used when an xsd is generated from the policy. The xsd in turn will be used to check the values given.
The property is represented by the attribute named 'type' in the policy file.

element.name: minOccurs
element.documentation:
How much time the property should be occur minimally in the objectClass. If no such property, then the value is deemed to be 1. It will be used when an xsd is generated from the policy. The xsd in turn will be used to check the values given.
The property is represented by the attribute with the same name in the policy file.

element.name: maxOccurs
element.documentation:
How much time the property should be occur maximally in the objectClass. If no such property, then there is no limit. It will be used when an xsd is generated from the policy. The xsd in turn will be used to check the values given.
The property is represented by the attribute with the same name in the policy file.

element.name: structural
element.documentation:
If the value of this property is "true", then the property is structural: The value will be generated by a default associated to it, and it is an error to enter the value into the model through some properties.
FIXME: this check is not implemented yet.
The property is represented by the attribute with the same name in the policy file.

element.name: def
element.documentation:
The id of a default related to the attribute.
The property is represented by a tag named 'type' in the policy file.

element.name: A composition relation points to the default from the attribute
default
element.documentation:
The default is used to describe how a property will get its default value if we have not given anything. It is useful to - describe and enforce structural relationships within the model - give default value to a property
This attribute should be entered as a property.

element.name: description
element.documentation:
The description of the default.
Ideally it describes how to give a value to the property through model structure, or what is the default value of the property, and why it is so.
The description is represented by the tag named 'description' in the policy file.

element.name: name of the parent node + the documentation of the parent node
element.documentation: By convention the 'how' and 'what' are described in the archimate element name, and the 'why' in its documentation.

element.name: order
element.documentation:
The order in which the defaults are evaluated. The default evaluation goes in the following way: 1. i:=0 2. if there is a default with order i, then try it. else stop. 3. if the default gave back a value, then stop. 4. i:= i+1 5. continue from 2.
Beware: if defaults are not numbered sequentially from zero, then some of them might not be tried. The reason of this behaviour that the sequence of getting the attributes from the policy programatically is not guaranteed to be the same as they are described there.
The property is represented by the attribute with the same name in the policy file.

element.name: select
element.documentation:
The xpath expression to be evaluated to get the value of the property. If multi="true", then the result should be a nodeset, else a string.
The property is represented by the attribute with the same name in the policy file.

element.name: multi
element.documentation:
Whether the select will return multiple values. If set to "true", then for each item in the nodelist returned by the select, a different property will be generated.
The property is represented by the attribute with the same name in the policy file. FIXME: there should be a "type" attribute instead, defaulting to string, with the following possible values: string: default functionality multi: multi="true" structured: works like xsl:copy-of

element.name: always
element.documentation:
Whether to try to always apply the default, even when there is already such a property.
The property is represented by the attribute with the same name in the policy file.

element.name: ArchimateObjectClass
element.documentation: An objectclass predefined by Archi. This does not show up in the policy file explicitly. Used to have a starting point to generate/document the objectClass hierarchy.

element.name: abstractNamed
element.documentation: This is an abstract class, so we don't need to define the name and description property for all objectClasses.

element.name: description
element.documentation:
The description of the objectClass.
The description is represented by the tag named 'description' in the policy file.

element.name: name
element.documentation:
name of the objectClass
The name is represented by an attribute named 'name' of the objectClass in the policy file.

element.name: admContact
element.documentation: Name of person

element.name: Application
element.documentation: An application or system.

element.name: ApplicationCollection
element.documentation: A collection of applications/systems that belong together eg. Salary payment.

element.name: The place where the physical hardware of the server is located
element.documentation: A Location assigned to the application

element.name: ipAddress
element.documentation: The IP address.

element.name: lifeCycleStatus
element.documentation: one of In preparation, In Test, In production, Under liquidation, Liquidated

element.name: location
element.documentation: where the PhysicalHardware is placed

element.name: networkZone
element.documentation: what network zone the server is placed in?

element.name: operatingSystem
element.documentation: what OS it runs?

element.name: physicalHardware
element.documentation: eg the physical server

element.name: Server
element.documentation: A server with an operating system, running on a physical or virtual hardware.

element.name: serverRole
element.documentation: e.g. Application server, File Server…

element.name: technicalContact
element.documentation: Name of person

element.name: This is the physical hardware the server is running on
element.documentation: Another Server which is composed of this one

element.name: The network zone the server runs on
element.documentation: A Network this Server is associated to

element.name: This is the operating system of the server
element.documentation: A System Software which have a composition from this Server

element.name: This is the role of the server in the big picture
element.documentation: An application function this server realizes

element.name: The life cycle phase
element.documentation: A Plateau which aggregates the server

element.name: The technically responsible person
element.documentation: An OrganisationalPerson which uses the Server with line text "operates"

element.name: The administratively responsible person
element.documentation: An OrganisationalPerson which uses the Server with line text "manages"

element.name: name
element.documentation: name of the stuff

element.name: Name of the object
element.documentation: Name

element.name: shortName
element.documentation: The name of the stuff.

element.name: server
element.documentation: The server(s) the application runs on

element.name: The server which realizes the application
element.documentation: A Server with a realisation relationship to the application

element.name: Salary app
element.documentation: The salary application

element.name: salary1.infirmary
element.documentation: The salary1 server

element.name: c64.infirmary
element.documentation: 64 kb RAM C< There is a trick here: a composition relation points from this to this. (dragged another instance of the node to the view, created a composition between the two instances, then removed the instance)

element.name: Financial apps
element.documentation: Financial applications

element.name: Tax avoidance flash applet
element.documentation: An application which keeps Latinum!

element.name: Legate Nesall
element.documentation: A legendary Cardassian architect

element.name: IT Architecture dept.
element.documentation: Where you look for an architect.

element.name: Odo
element.documentation: Chief security officer at Deep Space 9

element.name: IT Security dept.
element.documentation: Paranoid geeks.

element.name: Quark
element.documentation: The bar owner

element.name: Quark's
element.documentation: The bar at Deep Space 9.

element.name: DS9
element.documentation: The staff of Deep Space 9.

element.name: 3. Business Specification Acceptance
element.documentation:
The act of accepting the business specification.
The actor(s) related to this process step is deliberately missing, so you can have an error in the policy check output as an example.

element.name: 2. Business Specification Overview
element.documentation: Overview of the business specification.

element.name: 1. Creating business specification
element.documentation: The process in which the business specification is created.
Initial version
Added new version number and specialisation relation to it.

This module works with Archi 2.0.0. There is an event log window. It displays the warnings and errors when exporting the model.If a message contains a link to an element, you can jump to that element by clicking on the link. major restructure, now we have two modules. The new one is the browser modul originally developed by Phil to support the event log window. You can find user documentation and use cases under Use Cases. The Extended Archimate methodology is documented under introduction. The created report is shown in a browser window.
The followup release of Archi 2.2.0, featuring the new Motivation and Implementation & Migration extensions

element.name: archimate:BusinessCollaboration
element.documentation: See the archimate standard at http://www.opengroup.org/archimate/doc/ts_archimate/

element.name: archimate:Folder
element.documentation: A folder containing some elements of a model.

element.name: archimate:DataObject
element.documentation: See the archimate standard at http://www.opengroup.org/archimate/doc/ts_archimate/

element.name: archimate:BusinessActor
element.documentation: See the archimate standard at http://www.opengroup.org/archimate/doc/ts_archimate/

element.name: archimate:Product
element.documentation: See the archimate standard at http://www.opengroup.org/archimate/doc/ts_archimate/

element.name: archimate:BusinessEvent
element.documentation: See the archimate standard at http://www.opengroup.org/archimate/doc/ts_archimate/

element.name: archimate:BusinessProcess
element.documentation: See the archimate standard at http://www.opengroup.org/archimate/doc/ts_archimate/

element.name: archimate:Plateau
element.documentation: A plateau

element.name: archimate:model
element.documentation: The archimate model.

element.name: archimate:Node
element.documentation: A Node as defined by Archimate

element.name: archimate:ApplicationComponent
element.documentation: Application Component

element.name: report
element.documentation: folder properties to parameterize reports

element.name: part
element.documentation: The name of the report part for which this folder should be displayed

element.name: DocumentVersion
element.documentation: A Document version.

element.name: releasedate
element.documentation: The release date of the document version

element.name: versionnumber
element.documentation: The version number of the document version

element.name: authorid
element.documentation: The id of the author

element.name: A Realisation relation should point from the author to the document version
GovernanceStep
element.documentation: A governance process step. It is used to describe the related actors by the documentcontrol style.

element.name: state
element.documentation: The state of the step

element.name: actor
element.documentation: An actor involved in the step.

element.name: A used by relationship points from the author to the process step
OrganisationalUnit
element.documentation: An organisational unit.

element.name: OrganisationalPerson
element.documentation: A person belonging to an organisation

element.name: position
element.documentation:
position of the person
FIXME: should have a default which computes it by the composition relation with the organisation (property or line text), because it should actually change by organisation for the same person.

element.name: organisation
element.documentation: The (primary) organisation of the person.

element.name: More organisational units contains (Composition) the person, and one of the relations have a property with "primary" property.
element.documentation: When the person belongs to more organisational units, one of them should be the primary one. It is designated by a property added to the composition relationship.

element.name: Exactly one organisational unit contains (Composition) the person.
element.documentation: When the person belongs to one organisational unit, then this organisational unit is its primary organisation.

element.name: memberOf
element.documentation:
The organisations of the person.
FIXME: all Business Collaborations and Business Roles should have been listed here

element.name: Organisational units containing (Composition) the person.
element.documentation: All the organisational units which contain the person.

element.name: default style
element.documentation:
The default style gives us the same result as the built-in File/Report/HTML... menu in Archi. It is a flat enumeration of elements by architecture level and element type, followed by the diagrams
The example report made from this example model can be found at http://archistyledhtml.sourceforge.net/default.html

element.name: structured style
element.documentation:
The report contains the objects and diagrams in the same structure as they are in the model, with a table of contents.
For each folder it displays - any diagram in the folder - any element in the folder - the contents of the contained folders recursively
If you do not want an item (folder/element) to be displayed (e.g. no important information in the relations), you can add the report:hide attribute with a calue which evaluates to true (1 okay) to the folder. warning: in the future this might be changed to be report:part=hide.
The output might not be nice, but at least easy to overview. Cosmetic fixups are welcome, I am not good at visual design.
This is also an example of how one can use xslt to generate a html, and css to give a look to it.
You can find an example report output at http://archistyledhtml.sourceforge.net/

element.name: sketchtotable style
element.documentation:
This report style is to present the result of a brainstorming session using Nominal Group Technique (NGT).
See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nominal_group_technique for NGT.
How to use Archi during the session:
- Create a Sketch. Assign a property to it with the key 'objectClass', and value 'NGTresult'.
- In the "sharing ideas" step record each idea on a sticky.
- In the "group discussion" step organize stickies hierarchically. If idea A is considered to be a subset/instance of idea B, then place A within B. If A and B are in the same group, place them inside the same (possibly newly created) sticky.
- In the "voting and ranking" step place an element (we have only actor right now, it is okay) on the sketch. Each vote is represented by a connection between the element and a "main" sticky (which is not inside another one0.
Do not use connections for other purposes.
Presentation:
For each sketch having the NGTresult objectClass, a table is written. Rows represent a "main" sticky. The first cell contains the ranking (number of connections associated with) the idea. In the second cell you can find the content of the sticky. If there are more stickies inside the main one, they are presented hierarchically in a list.
possible enhancements (notify me if you want them, and I may implement it)
- We might have a label for a sticky. E.g. if there is a "::" in the contents, then everything before it is the label. it could be displayed in a column. - We might allow connections between elements, by designating one connection type to votes (so the others could be used for other purposes. - (It needs additional code in Archi) The stickies in the sketch could be automatically turned into archimate elements. By using properties cleverly, even a mapping from sticky color to folder and element type could be done. Note that Phil seems to work on it.

element.name: documentcontrol style
element.documentation:
An example style mplementing the usual document control functionality, and the objectclasses.
Lists the versions sorted by version number, then the actors used for two named process steps.
This example contains a postprocessor written in python. It generates a policy file called "newpolicy.xml".
See http://archistyledhtml.sourceforge.net/documentcontrol.html for an example.

element.name: Properties tab
element.documentation: It is at Edit/Preferences/Styled Export.

element.name: file dialog
element.documentation:
This is where you choose files and directories.
FIXME: there are some minor usage problems with this widget which should be fixed.

element.name: problem report
element.documentation: A dialog stating the problem. If such a dialog appears, some additional information may be available in the stdout/stderr of the application, the application log, or the eventlog. See troubleshooting for details.

element.name: browser window
element.documentation: The browser is used to display event log and report output

element.name: xmlitem
element.documentation: An xml item describes a model, entity or attribute.

element.name: parent
element.documentation: the parent of the item

element.name: type
element.documentation: type of the item - model - entity - attribute reference

element.name: name
element.documentation: the name of the item

element.name: value
element.documentation: value of the item

element.name: label
element.documentation: used for access control

element.name: report:part
element.documentation: This property tells us which part of the model to gerenate. There is a corresponding stylesheet parameter named part. The documentation by default will recursively contain all elements in folders below the marked model/folder (see also the noroot stylesheet parameter).

element.name: report:role
element.documentation: This parameter is to restrict the visibility of some parts of the model, based on the target audience. There is a corresponding stylesheet parameter named role. The objects and/or folders marked with report:role will be generated only if the stylesheet parameter's value is the same as the property's value. It is not possible to use more than one role neither as a property nor as a stylesheet parameter. If you would need this, please file a bug report. If you also want to handle diagrams properly, you have to utilize the split xml stylesheet. There is a corresponding xml tag to mark parts of the element documentation named only, with the role attribute, used in the obvious way.

element.name: from-folder
element.documentation:
This property holds the id of a folder, and folders can be marked with it. All elements from the referenced folder will be added to the documentation of the referring folder, but diagrams, sketches and folders.
Yes, it is the id of the model element which is a bit complicated to figure out (you should look at the model's xml). It does not change if you change the name of the element, and it is not ambigous. If you can come up with a better way, and you actually need it then file a bug report.

element.name: copy-image
element.documentation: inserts a diagram to where it is referenced

element.name: part
element.documentation: See the report:part model property.

element.name: noroot
element.documentation: If this parameter is set, then the folders below the one marked with the report:part property will be documented.

element.name: role
element.documentation: Please see the report:role property.

element.name: Silly question
element.documentation: After the folder is choosen, Archi asks whether you want to delete this directory. It a bug, ignore it

element.name: Move around
element.documentation: The ability to move objects freely in the model's hierarchy. This supports the structured display of views and objects belonging to that view. It is used by not just the structured style, which is a base for the majority of report styles used in real life. A patch is already submitted

element.name: Enterprise repository
element.documentation: An enterprise repository would be very nice. It could be done using CDO. There is already a proof of concept code, but a major restructure would be needed.

element.name: Persistence layer
element.documentation: Currently the whole code mixes business logic and GUI. It should be sorted out to be able to correctly support batch report generation and enterprise repository.

element.name: is there anything you can add?

item.label: 4. Stakeholders
item.documentation: We can see the players of the game here

item.label: 2. Modeling
item.documentation: In the modeling phase, you describe something (the thing which is modeled) based on some ontology (the metamodel), resulting in a model. The Archimate methodology gives us a metamodel, which is directly useable with Archi. However often you need a metamodel more detailed than that.

item.label: 1. Simple uses
item.documentation: For simple uses you don't even need a metamodel.

item.label: Creating docbook (and html) documentation
item.documentation:
In some cases you just want to create a documentation which contains all, or some parts of the model. The docbook style - which is the successor of the structured style - does just that for you. There are actually two style files shipped: docbook.style creates index.docbook and docbookandhtml.style creates index.docbook and index.html. The documentation will contain the directories as docbook sections, with the diagrams first, then all the contained elements in a table as rows. The element documentation contains the element properties, except the ones known by the style and objectClass. The style is able to convert a very limited subset of html markup in the documentation to docbook (and then html). Beware that anything looking like html and not in that subset is silently omitted from the output. As too much element documentation means too few modeling, I won't go into more details, see unescape.xslt. If you really need more, please submit a working github pull request with a test case and I might include it. The style is customizable in two ways:
  • model properties: there are properties which define which parts of the model will be actually generated. With the unmodified style, you should set the report:part property to all for the model or a directory.
  • stylesheet properties: if you open the style file with a text editor, you will see a line containing the name of the xml stylesheet (docbook.xslt) doing the bulk of the work, and some parameters passed to the stylesheet. These are customizable using any text editor. I recommend saving the style file in another name in the same directory before that.
If you would need any more customisation of the style, please file a bug report.

item.label: tuning the html output
item.documentation: At the moment you should edit xslt/docbook2html.xslt don't be afraid, it is short and easy. This step uses the docbook-xsl stylesheets, for which you can see the parameter reference here: http://docbook.sourceforge.net/release/xsl/1.75.2/doc/html/

item.label: 2. Metamodels
item.documentation: Every model have some ontology as a background. In a lot of cases it is implicit, but there are cases when it is better to define it exactly. For example a well defined ontology is the basis for any model driven code/configuration generation. Another case is when you want to check your or others' work for mistakes and omissions. These cases need a well-defined set of rules about the subject matter. The ontology is captured in Archi as a metamodel, and based on it a policy is generated. The policy is then used by the rich export functionality to emit warnings about nonconformances, and to export the model in a way which is easily used by stylesheets to generate the necessary data.

item.label: 1. Defining a metamodel
item.documentation: The current way to define the metamodel is not considered to be the final one, however most probably I will keep this method as well. In the future metamodels will be defined by template diagrams, where the relations of a template object will define its attributes and the way the attributes obtain their value. Also the extension methods defined by Archimate 2.0 will be fully taken into account. The concepts are already very similar (maybe v2.0 was partly modeled by the Extended Archimate concept, see the history section), but I yet to check that the standard is actually followed. The core concept of the metamodel is objectClass. The objectClass tells us that we are facing a specialisation of an Archimate object (or any object defined by Archi, like Folder or model). As an example, we can have an Application Service with the objectClass WebService. In the metamodel level an objectclass have a parent (a built-in objectclass or a descendant thereof), and maybe some attributes. The attributes themselves have various properties, which may have default values. In the next sections we figure out how to define the objectClass for an Archimate object, and we learn how to define a metamodel.

item.label: 2. policy related objectClasses
item.documentation: The metamodel below tells us exactly how to define what attributes an object belonging to an objectClass may and must have, and how can the value of an attribute be computed if it is not directly given (as we have seen above). Also there are plenty of examples of objectClass and attribute value definitions.

item.label: objectClass
item.documentation: This objectClass describes an objectClass. Recursion rulez.

item.label: 2. Creating a policy, checking policy conformance, quick export for xml-aware tools
item.documentation: You need policy.style for that. It uses the "built-in" policy (generated from this model) to generate a policy named "policy.xml" in the target directory, then uses the generated policy on the model, exporting "archirich.xml" an object list in html and docbook format, and a couple of cvs files in the csvdir directory. Any policy violation is logged as an error. As an example running policy.style in this model should result in exactly one error in both rounds; there is a deliberate omission in the model to show this feature. You can click on the log and it navigates you to the offending element. The file "archirich.xml" will contain elements for each instances of extended archimate objects. These elements are named after the objectClass's name, and contain one element for each of the attributes: the informations are already assembled (maybe from parts of the model far away from each other) for use by xml-aware tools. An example of such xml-aware tools is the xslts running in the next step, creating the objectlist docbook and html files contain the list of objects, as well as csv files for each objectClass. If you need anything more (for example harsher error handling) just drop a bug report.

item.label: Extended Archimate
item.documentation:
The Archimate 2 standard have introduced methods to extend the underlying metamodel of Archimate.
The StyledHtml module will go along these lines. For historical purposes you can find my proposal from Archimate 1 times here:
This is a proposal for an extension to Archimate methodology, adding a metamodel layer in the following way: - Instances of Archimate objects can have properties. This extension is already implemented in Archi. - There is a 4th layer above the well-known ones: the ontology/metamodel layer, describing concepts derived from core archimate concepts, and the properties associated with that concept. - A new concept of the ontology should be either a simple one, or a composite one. There are the following constraints to derive concepts of an ontology: - A simple concept should be derived from a core concept of the Archimate ontology. - A composite concept is a structure built from simple concepts. A composite concept is a "macro": it is defined by and can always be replaced with a structure of simple concepts, and all properties of the composite concept can be bound to a simple concept in the underlying structure.
As you can see Extended Archimate is not another arbitrary methodology, because: - A model described in the extended archimate methodology can always be described in the core archimate methodology. Moreover a model described in ontology B can be described in ontology A, if B is derived from A. - Because of the above, all reasoning which holds for the core archimate methodology will hold for any ontology B based on it. Moreover for each ontology A, and B where B is derived from A, all reasoning for A will hold for B. - If there would be a methodology which incompatible with archimate - in the sense that models using that methodology cannot be meaningfully described in archimate - it would not be describeable in the extended methodology either (but archimate is capable to describe everything, so it is merely a theoretical point:). - Models using other methodology could be described by first defining the ontology of the other methodology in EA ontology layer, making archimate the mother of all methodologies:)
Reasoning for the necessity of EA: Archimate right now is a closed ontology. It does have a lot of advantages, and EA would not loose any of them, because any model in EA should have a representation in the core ontology. But a closed ontology is not capable to describe our world in the necessary detail . When you start any design work, the first step is to create a view of the world around you. Let's take a sentence from the standard itself to illustrate it: "Examples of business actors are humans, departments, and business units." So to have the descriptive power, the ontology should be open "downward". This means that archimate as it is would not be able to support a design beyond a point. The more you focus only on some aspects of the world, the deeper you can go using Archimate, but it comes with the cost that you should neglect other aspects, otherwise they would interfere with your model. And there is invariably a point where another methodology should be used, and the model you built can no longer fully serve the purpose of being a reference point. When you gave your model to a developer and he should rebuild it in UML (or just don't have a frame of thought to develop your model further), it is not just a waste of effort, but makes communication harder because the differing views on the world. For us security people who should care with all the layers and from the conception to the details, this is a nightmare. With extended archimate the whole development cycle would be traceable in one model, refining not just the model but the ontology with it as development progresses. This makes automated checks for model structure and content reasonable, and even generation of code and configuration is possible. This not just gives the opportunity to help the uninitiated to make quality work, and give the tedious work to machines, but also helps traceability across the different levels of detail. If you ever tried to figure out whether a high-level requirement is fully implemented across a complex system, you will know what I am talking about.

item.label: repository of servers and systems
item.documentation: See the Server list, the the Application list, and the The ApplicationCollection list. For the details, see the section about metamodels. On Monday, 31 January 2011 23:26:06 UTC+1, TerChris wrote: Hi First of all I’m pleased to find a tool that I think will help me in creating a repository of servers, systems and the dependencies between them. I was on a project earlier where we used www.troux.com Architect (ver8). Troux Architect is not a cheap tool and we cannot justify the cost of it on the project I’m working at now. I want to do the same as I did in the “troux-project”. That is to create a repository of all servers, systems, dependencies and the people responsible for running/administering/developing each item. I want to model this structure. Server attributes: PhysicalHardware (eg the physical server) Location (where the PhysicalHardware is placed) ServerName (the name of the server) IP Address Status (In preparation, In Test, In production, Under liquidation, Liquidated) NetworkZone (what network zone the server is placed) OperatingSystem (what OS it runs) ServerRole (Application server, File Server…) TechnicalContact (Name of person) Application attributes: (a application or system) ApplicationName (name of the system) TechnicalContact (Name of person) AdmContact (Name of person) Application collection: (A collection of applications/systems that belong together eg Sallary payment) CollectionName (name of the collection of applications) AdmContact (Name of person) I then want to create a model view for each Application collection that shows: What applications the collection consists of. What dependencies there are between the applications in the collection and to applications outside the collection. What servers the applications run on What PhysicalHardware the servers run on (physical or a vmware) Is this possible using Archi? I can’t see a way to add more properties to a device. Is it not possible? Regards Terje

item.label: life cycle stages
item.documentation: Actually there should be an objectClass for them.

item.label: Document Control
item.documentation:
This is metadata about the model. Contains the information which serves as a base for generating the version and review control part of the resulting reports.
Note that as the application itself is about document control in a way, sometimes it is hard to differentiate between business and governance related processes/actors. To make it easier, the strictly governance related elments will be distinct from the business process related ones, using fictional characters and distinct process steps, although sometimes with the same name. To show the normal overlap between business process stakeholders and governance actors (the business itself) we use real persons.

item.label: builtin object classes
item.documentation: These are the object classes defined by the archimate standard. Only the one which are actually used in the metamodel are documented.

item.label: report styles
item.documentation: The report styles shipped with the styledhtml module

item.label: Java classes
item.documentation: In a real-world scenario, this low level is often designed in

item.label: Sample policy
item.documentation: There is a sample policy associated with some shipped report styles. We describe the objectclasses used in them here.
